Subject: Re: [neat] Continuous Species Control
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=29390171; y=8cT5W3PjVeIS5hUnf0CBKBZbwM4S2rarW_R6Rhv2VBfDvehEOnPeLa4R9-0
X-Yahoo-Profile: mattias_fagerlund

Hey,

 
> Just remember about optimisation being the root of all evil. I've 
> introduced some pretty nasty bugs into code in the name of
> optimisation, 

For Delphi Neat, I used an "optimized" version of exp, because it was
significantly faster. What I didn't know was that it wasn't as accurate.
That exp function totally killed the effectiveness of NEAT, and it took me
days before I realized it was the exp function that was causing the
problems...

> Hence my train of thought moves 
> to hebbian learning based algorithms - the idea of connection hardness 
> gives us something like that. 

Hardness, is that resistance to mutation, like preventing weight mutation
and connection splitting? I could see potential benefits to that. Would
hardness be related to connection age, or evolved as a separate value,
along with the connection weight? 

One interesting solution would be to initialize all new connections with a
hardness of zero, then let the hardness evolve freely. Evolution should
make essential connection hardened because mutations to them would
decrease the survivability of the species/individual...

Today, evolution fumbles blindly, changing everything around "trying" to
make improvements instead of focusing on the weak parts of the current
network. Perhaps hardness would be a way around that?

I've often wondered what would happen if you "locked" nodes and
connections after they reached a certain age, focusing evolution on coming
up with new structures to tweak old behaviours instead of evolving all of it. 

Is there any research on these topics that I could look at?

cheers,
mattias
